name: Carb Cycling Diet
goal: Optimize body composition by alternating carbohydrate intake to match training demands, supporting muscle growth while minimizing fat gain.
best_for: Individuals seeking muscle gain with controlled fat accumulation or cutting phases

caloric_strategy.maintenance: Estimate TDEE using Mifflin-St Jeor or Cunningham equation. Adjust weekly.
caloric_strategy.surplus: Moderate surplus (≈ 5–15% above TDEE). Carb levels dictate daily calorie variations.

protein.rationale: Supports muscle protein synthesis regardless of carb cycle.

meal_timing.protein_distribution: 20–40 g protein per meal, every 3–5 hr

high_carb_training_days.pre_workout: Carbs + protein (e.g., oats + soy milk + protein powder)
high_carb_training_days.post_workout: 1–1.5 g/kg carbs + 20–40 g protein within 2 hr

meal_timing.low_carb_days: Focus on protein, fibrous veggies, and healthy fats

supplements: Electrolytes (Na, K, Mg) for high-sweat training days

monitoring.body_weight: Weekly average; adjust calories if outside 0.25–0.5% BW gain/week
monitoring.performance_markers: Assess energy differences across carb days

advantages: Matches carb intake to energy demands
May improve insulin sensitivity and nutrient partitioning
Helps balance muscle growth with fat control
Provides psychological variety compared to static diets
limitations: Requires meal prep and detailed tracking
Large fluctuations in intake may affect mood/energy for some individuals
Evidence mostly indirect, not from long-term RCTs
references: Kerksick CM et al. (2017). ISSN Position Stand: Nutrient Timing. JISSN, 14:33.
Morton RW et al. (2018). Protein supplementation meta-analysis. Br J Sports Med, 52(6):376–384.
Slater GJ & Phillips SM (2011). Nutrition guidelines for strength sports. J Sports Sci, 29 Suppl 1:S67–77.
Helms ER, Aragon AA, Fitschen PJ (2014). Evidence-based recommendations for natural bodybuilding contest prep. JISSN, 11:20.
ACSM (2022). Nutrition and Athletic Performance Position Stand.
